docs.snippet: Anti-American sentiment, always strong in Latin America, has only grown more acute in recent times, largely because Washington has treated us with indifference and disrespect since 9/11.
docs.lead_paragraph: Anti-American sentiment, always strong in Latin America, has only grown more acute in recent times, largely because Washington has treated us with indifference and disrespect since 9/11.

docs.snippet: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y....
docs.lead_paragraph: A guide to cultural and recreational goings-on in and around Connecticut this week. Items for the guide should be sent at least three weeks in advance to ctcal@nytimes.com, or by mail to Connecticut Weekly, 229 West 43rd Street, New York, N.Y. 10036-3959. MUSIC AND DANCE Bridgeport ''Late Night Noon,'' presented by Catie Curtis. March 11 at 6 p.m. $22. Johnny Durkin's ''Manchado,'' Latin jazz, featuring Rich Zurkowski, Rob Somerville, and others. Thursday at 9 p.m. $5. Scarecrow Collection with Clarias and The Vanderbilts. Friday at 9 p.m. $5. The Cosmic Jibaros, Latin rock. March 17 at 9 p.m. $8. Steve Clarke, jazz. March 18 at 5 p.m. $10. Acoustic Cafe, 2926 Fairfield Avenue. (203) 335-3655. Fairfield ''Pardon My English: A Gershwin Portrait,'' presented by Orchestra New England, conducted by James Sinclair. March 17 at 8 p.m. $30 and $35. Quick Center for the Arts, 1073 North Benson Road. (203) 254-4010. Hartford ''My Eire,'' celebration of Irish composers, presented by Jason Charneski and Friends. March 17 at 1:30 p.m. Free. Center Church, 60 Gold St. (860) 249-5631. Hartford Stephen Michael Gryc's ''Passaggi: Concerto for Trombone and Orchestra'' and other works, presented by the Hartford Symphony Orchestra with Joseph Alessi, trombone. Friday and March 16 at 7:30 p.m. $30; students, $10. The Bushnell Center for Performing Arts, 166 Capitol Avenue. (860) 987-5900. New Haven ''Afternoon Dances,'' presented by Willie Feuer, Susan Matheke and others. March 18 at 2 p.m. Free. ECA Arts Hall, Orange and Audubon Street. (860) 346-2210. New Haven Steve Davis Quintet with Mike DiRubbo, alto saxophone. Friday at 8:30 and 10 p.m. $10 to $15. Firehouse 12, 45 Crown Street. (203) 785-0468. New Haven ''The Rat Pack Live at the Sands,'' tribute to the music of Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, and Sammy Davis Jr. Tuesday through March 18. $38 to $68. Shubert Theater, 247 College Street. (203) 624-1825. Newtown Works by Mozart, Devienne and Schumann, performed by the Walden Chamber Players. March 11 at 3 p.m. $18; seniors, $16; children 14 and under, free. Edmond Town Hall, 45 Main Street. (203) 426-6470. Old Lyme Works by Beethoven, Dvorak and Fauré, performed by Karen Gomyo, violin, Kenji Bunch, viola, Andrés Díaz, cello, and Erika Nickrenz and Charles Wadsworth, piano. March 17 at 5 p.m. and March 18 at 3 p.m. $5 to $30. First Congregational Church of Old Lyme, 2 Ferry Road. (860) 767-1833. Ridgefield Marc Cohn, singer-songwriter. March 11 at 8 p.m. $55.50 to $76. Ridgefield Playhouse, 80 East Ridge Avenue. (203) 438-5795. Ridgefield Pat Wictor, blues-based roots. March 18 at 7 p.m. $15 to $20. Temple Shearith Israel, 46 Peaceable Street. (201) 431-6501. Southport Larry Coryell with Paul Wertico and Mark Egan, jazz fusion. March 18 at 4 p.m. $40; under 18, $5. Pequot Library, 720 Pequot Avenue. (203) 938-3843. Stamford ''Dueling Organists,'' concert presented by Jay Peterson and Stephen Rapp. March 18 at 4 p.m. Donation. St. John's Lutheran Church, 884 Newfield Avenue. (203) 322-0066. Storrs Inti-Illimani, Chilean ensemble. Thursday at 8 p.m. $21 to $30. Jorgensen Center for the Performing Arts, 2132 Hillside Road, University of Connecticut. (860) 486-4226. Torrington ''The Irish Rovers,'' Irish music. Wednesday at 8 p.m. $19.50 to $50. Warner Theater, 68 Main Street. (860) 489-7180. THEATER Darien ''Wait Until Dark'' by Frederick Knott, directed by Dan Friedman. Through March 24. $20; seniors, $15; children under 12, $5. Darien Arts Center Weatherstone Theater, 2 Renshaw Road. (203) 655-5414. Hartford ''Breakfast, Lunch and Dinner,'' comedy by Luis Alfaro, directed by Lisa Peterson. Through April 1. $22 to $57. Hartford Stage, 50 Church Street. (860) 527-5151. Hartford ''Composition,'' by Timothy McCraken, featuring Tommy Schrider and Tara Falk. Through March 11. $35 to $45. TheaterWorks Hartford, 233 Pearl Street. (860) 527-7838. New Milford ''Dog Sees God: Confession of a Teenage Blockhead,'' by Bert V. Royal, directed by Susan Pettibone. Through March 17. $18.50. Creative Arts Center, PO Box 836. (860) 350-6863. Ridgefield ''The Search For Signs of Intelligent Life in the Universe,'' directed by Marc Cameron, written by Jane Wagner. Through March 24. $18 and $22. Ridgefield Theater Barn, 37 Halpin Lane. (203) 431-9850. Waterbury ''Viagara Falls,'' comedy by Joao Machado and Lou Cutell, directed by Don Crichton. Thursday through April 15. $27 to $45. Seven Angels Theater, Plank Road in Hamilton Park Pavillion. (203) 757-4676. FILM Wilton Enviro Flicks: ''Sacred Planet,'' directed by Jon Long. March 11 at 2 p.m. Free; reservations recommended. Wilton Library, 137 Old Ridgefield Road. (203) 762-3950. FOR CHILDREN Bridgeport ''Peter Rabbit,'' staged version of the Beatrix Potter book. Through April 1. $13.50. Downtown Cabaret Theater, 263 Golden Hill Street. (203) 576-1636. Bridgeport ''Creativity Ignited!'' Interactive children's exhibit exploring the imagination. Through April 30. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. The Discovery Museum, 4450 Park Avenue. (203) 372-3521. Fairfield ''Henry and Mudge,'' adaptation of the children's book. Ages 4 to 8. March 18 at 1 and 3 p.m. $10 and $12. Quick Center for the Arts, 1073 North Benson Road. (203) 254-4010. Fairfield ''A Very Old Man With Enormous Wings,'' adapted by Nilo Cruz from a short story by Gabriel Garcia Márquez. Ages 12 and up. Through March 18. $10 to $18. Sacred Heart University (Edgerton Center for the Performing Arts), 5151 Park Avenue. (203) 371-7908. Glastonbury ''Whales.'' Learn about whales. Ages 5 to 9. Tuesday at 4 p.m. $13; members, $10. The Connecticut Audubon Society Center at Glastonbury, 1361 Main Street. (860) 633-8402. Ridgefield ''Wizard of Oz,'' presented by the Young People's Theater. All ages. March 18 at 11 a.m. and 2 p.m. $15. Ridgefield Playhouse, 80 East Ridge Avenue. (203) 438-5795. Waterbury ''Wizard of Oz,'' presented by the Young People's Theater. March 17 at 3 p.m. $7. John F. Kennedy High School Auditorium, Highland Avenue. (203) 577-2377. West Hartford ''Color Play: The Art and Science of Color and Light.'' Explore light and holographic refraction. Ages 12 and under. Through June 17. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. The Children's Museum, 950 Trout Brook Drive. (860) 231-2824. West Haven ''Robin Hood,'' presented by Alliance Children's Theater, directed by Elizabeth Hines. Through March 18. $6. Dodds Auditorium, University of New Haven, (203) 932-7246. Westport ''The Fantastic Mr. Fox,'' adapted from Roald Dahl, presented by Signstage Theater. March 18 at 1 and 4:30 p.m. $15. Westport Country Playhouse, 25 Powers Court. (203) 227-4177. OUTDOORS Glastonbury ''Nutmeg Cougars,'' discussion led by Bill Betty. March 18 at 7 p.m. $7; members, $5. The Connecticut Audubon Society Center at Glastonbury, 1361 Main Street. (860) 633-8402. SPOKEN WORD Mystic ''Adventure Series,'' lecture about the Montagnard people of northern Vietnam by Milton Clark. Thursday at 2 and 7:30 p.m. $9 to $15. Mystic Seaport, 75 Germanville Avenue. (860) 572-0711. New Canaan Elizabeth Aston, author of ''The Second Mrs. Darcy.'' Monday at 10 a.m. Free. New Canaan Library, 151 Main Street. (203) 594-5000. Old Greenwich Kevin Sessums, author of ''Mississippi Sissy.'' March 11 at 1 p.m. Free. Arcadia Coffee Company, 20 Arcadia Road. (203) 637-8766. Waterbury Frances Mayes, author of ''Under the Tuscan Sun.'' Thursday at 7:30 p.m. $35. Palace Theater of Connecticut, 100 East Main Street. (203) 755-4700. MUSEUMS AND GALLERIES Brookfield ''The Sound of Earth: Ceramic Musical Instruments,'' works by Rod Kendall, Susan Rawcliffe and others. Through March 18. Hours: Mondays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Brookfield Craft Center, 286 Whisconier Road. (203) 775-4526. Fairfield ''Multiple Visions: Traveling Art Boxes from Argentina, Mexico and Uruguay,'' works by more than 20 artists. Through March 11. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Thomas J. Walsh Art Galley, 1073 North Benson Road. (203) 254-4000. Guilford ''Exhibition of Miniatures,'' works by Tom Edwards, Gail Friedland and others. Friday through April 22. Reception: Friday, 5 to 7 p.m. Guilford Art Center, 411 Church Street. (203) 453-5947. Hartford ''Logicals + Cakes,'' acrylic cakes by Bolek Niedzwiecki. Through March 31. Donation: $3; members, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Thursdays and Sundays, 2 to 10 p.m.; Fridays and Saturdays, 2 p.m. to midnight. Real Art Ways, 56 Arbor Street. (860) 232-1006. Hartford ''Soul Food: African American Cooking and Creativity,'' art and artifacts exploring Southern cooking and culture; presented by the Amistad Center for Art and Culture. Through April 22. ''Faith and Fortune: Five Centuries of European Masterworks,'' exhibition of European masterworks and sculpture from the museum's collection. Through Dec. 9. ''Picasso to Pop: Aspects of Modern Art,'' exhibition of the museum's holdings from many 20th-century genres. Through Nov. 18. $3 to $10; members and children 12 and under, free. Hours: Wednesdays through Fridays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; first Thursdays of the month, 11 a.m. to 8 p.m. Wadsworth Atheneum Museum of Art, 600 Main Street. (860) 838-4058. Mashantucket ''Booming Out: Mohawk Ironworkers Build New York,'' photographs and sculpture documenting the Mohawk sky-walking construction tradition passed through six generations. Through May 27. $10 to $15; children under 6, free. Hours: Daily, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; last admission, 3 p.m. Mashantucket Pequot Museum and Research Center, 110 Pequot Trail. (800) 411-9671. Middletown ''Etching Since 1950.'' Through April 8. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Davison Art Center, 301 High Street, Wesleyan University. (860) 685-2500. Middletown Middletown Public Schools Art Exhibition. Through March 18. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Ezra and Cecile Zilkha Gallery, Wesleyan University, 283 Washington Terrace. (860) 685-3355. Milford ''Black and White,'' juried group exhibition of non-color works. Through April 5. Hours: Thursdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Firehouse Art Gallery, 81 Naugatuck. (203) 306-0016. New Canaan ''Roof to Roof,'' works by Linda Adato. Through March 11. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5 p.m. Silvermine Guild Arts Center, 1037 Silvermine Road. (203) 966-9700, Extension 14. New Haven ''New Haven's Garment Workers: An Elm City Story,'' photographs and artifacts documenting the 20th century garment industry. Through May 4. Free. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to noon. Ethnic Heritage Center, 270 Fitch Street. (203) 392-6126. New Haven ''Roadside Attractions,'' photographs by 17 regional artists. Through Friday. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m. Small Space Gallery, 70 Audubon Street. (203) 772-2788. New Haven ''Howard Hodgkin: Paintings 1992-2007.'' Through April 1. Free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Yale Center for British Art, 1080 Chapel Street. (203) 432-2800. New Haven ''UNStudio: Evolution of Space,'' exhibition of five projects by the Amsterdam-based firm. Through May 4. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 9 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Yale School of Architecture Gallery, 180 York Street. (203) 432-2889. New Haven ''Jasper Johns: From Plate to Print.'' Through April 1. ''Making a Mark: Four Contemporary Artists in Print,'' prints by Enrique Chagoya, Carroll Dunham, Jane Hammond and Kiki Smith. Through April 1. ''Made for Love: Selections From the Jane Katcher Collection of Americana,'' 30 works of art that focus on the ways love and friendship are expressed through gift exchange. Through Aug. 26. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Thursdays, 10 a.m. to 8 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 6 p.m. Yale University Art Gallery, (203) 432-0600. Old Lyme ''The Freedom Business: Connecticut Landscapes Through the Eyes of Venture Smith,'' poems by Marilyn Nelson paired with paintings from the museum's collection. Through June 24. ''A Collective Endeavor: Three Decades of Acquisitions.'' Through March 25. $4 to $8; under 6, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, 1 to 5p. Florence Griswold Museum, 96 Lyme Street. (860) 434-5542. Ridgefield ''The Photograph as Canvas,'' works by artists who draw or paint on photographs. March 11 through June 10. ''Tekrar,'' sound installation by David Abir. March 11 through Aug. 12. ''W(E)AVE,'' sound and textile collaboration between Elana Herzog and Michael Schumacher. March 11 through Aug. 12. ''Blow Ups: Spores, Pollen, and Pollutants,'' works by Kysa Johnson. March 11 through June 10. ''Castles, Dwarfs, and Happychaps,'' work by Arturo Herrera created using the Renaissance technique of pouncing. March 11 through Sept. 2. ''Chrysanthemum Anthems,'' sculpture by Dario Robleto based on United States soldiers' experiences of wars. March 11 through June 17. Reception for all exhibits: March 11, 3 to 5 p.m. $7; seniors and students, $4; members, K-12 teachers and children under 18, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Aldrich Contemporary Art Museum, 258 Main Street. (203) 438-4519. Stamford ''Great Dames Part Trois,'' works by female artists. Through April 10. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 11 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Loft Artist Gallery at Yale and Towne, 737 Canal Street. (203) 323-4153. Stamford ''Urban Dreamscapes, Stamford as a Work of Art,'' featuring work by Renee Kahn. Through March 31. Hours: Mondays through Thursdays, 8:30 a.m. to 7 p.m.; Fridays, 8:30 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Saturdays, 9 a.m. to noon. University of Connecticut Stamford Campus Art Gallery, Broad Street and Washington Boulevard. (203) 251-8400. Storrs ''Intemperate Times: Kathe Kollwitz, 1918-1934.'' Through May 6. ''Tradition and Innovation: Latin American Art From the Benton Collection.'' Tuesday through June 17. Hours: Tuesdays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4:30 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, 1 to 4:30 p.m. William Benton Museum of Art, 245 Glenbrook Road. (860) 486-4520. Waterbury ''From Colonial Village to Country Retreat,'' exhibition exploring the architectural history of Middlebury. Through April 7. $4; children under 16, free. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 10 a.m. to 5 p.m.; Sundays, noon to 5 p.m. Mattatuck Museum Arts and History Center, 144 West Main Street. (303) 753-0381. Westport ''Art and the Good Earth: As Seen Through the Painter's Eye,'' works by 14 artists. Through May 11. Hours: Mondays through Fridays, 10 a.m. to 4 p.m.; Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 4 p.m. Westport Historical Society, 25 Avery Place. (203) 224-1424. Willimantic ''Indigo: Traditional Chinese Blue Textiles.'' Through April 22. $5; students and seniors, $3.50. Hours: Fridays through Sundays, 1 to 4 p.m. Windham Textile and History Museum, 411 Main Street. (860) 456-2178.

docs.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   3-18    Regional Talks Begin in Iraq  Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq opened a much-anticipated regional security conference in Baghdad with a plea to Iraq's neighbors to refuse to finance attacks in Iraq or allow people...
docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL 3-18 Regional Talks Begin in Iraq Prime Minister Nuri Kamal al-Maliki of Iraq opened a much-anticipated regional security conference in Baghdad with a plea to Iraq's neighbors to refuse to finance attacks in Iraq or allow people to cross borders in order to participate in them as suicide bombers or militia members. 1 On one of the holiest days in the Shiite calendar, a suicide car bomber detonated a vehicle outside a military checkpoint near Sadr City, a Shiite stronghold, killing at least seven Iraqi soldiers and three pilgrims and wounding scores of civilians, officials said. 16 Estimates of the number of Shiite pilgrims traveling to Karbala for Arbaeen, the Shiite ritual commemorating the killing of the Prophet Muhammad's grandson, ranged from three million to seven million. Iraqi officials said this was the largest celebration of the holiday in decades. Bush Continues Tour in Uruguay President Bush continued his tour of Latin America in Uruguay, meeting with President Tabaré Vázquez, a left-leaning leader who has shown a willingness to buck the anti-American push of regional strongmen. 4 In Colombia, the president's next stop, a scandal tying paramilitary death squads and drug traffickers to close supporters of President Álvaro Uribe threatens to overshadow Mr. Bush's brief visit. 4 Hungary's Rallying Cry During protests in Hungary last October, the government put up barriers around Parliament. Despite international pressure to take them down, they still stand, and they have become a symbol for opposition in a country with a history of protest. 6 Dismay Over U.N. Rights Panel The newly formed United Nations Human Rights Council is set to begin a session in Geneva amid expressions of frustration from rights advocates at its early performance. 8 NATIONAL 20-27 Romney's Gifts to the Right In the months before announcing his bid for the Republican presidential nomination, former Gov. Mitt Romney of Massachusetts contributed tens of thousands of dollars of his personal fortune to several conservative groups in a position to influence his image on the right. 1 Couples Separate to Sleep Not since the Victorian age of starched sheets and starchy manners, builders and architects say, have there been so many orders for separate bedrooms. Couples and sociologists say that often it has to do with snoring, and getting a good night's sleep. 1 Iraqi Refugees in America As the violence rages in Iraq and tens of thousands flee to neighboring countries, a small stream of Iraqis is trickling into the United States despite improbable odds. 20 NEW YORK/REGION 29-34 Bridging a Muslim Divide The congregations of the Mosque of Islamic Brotherhood in Harlem, serving African-Americans, and the Islamic Center of Long Island, serving immigrants of South Asian and Arab descent, represent the largest Muslim populations in the United States. Yet a gulf divides them, one marked by race, class and history. 1 New Life for Local Newspapers Last fall, Rupert Murdoch purchased TimesLedger Newspapers, a chain of 16 local weeklies in Queens, reflecting the vigor of community weeklies and marking a new period for the borough's independent newspapers. 1 Chess 33 Weather SP 12

docs.snippet: President Bush acknowledged on Saturday ''F.B.I. shortfallings'' in the disclosure that the bureau improperly used the USA Patriot Act to obtain thousands of business, financial and other records in the United States.     But at a news briefing in...
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush acknowledged on Saturday ''F.B.I. shortfallings'' in the disclosure that the bureau improperly used the USA Patriot Act to obtain thousands of business, financial and other records in the United States. But at a news briefing in Uruguay, part of a weeklong trip to Latin America, Mr. Bush said the provision that was misused remained an important tool against terrorism.
docs.abstract: Pres Bush acknowledges FBI acted improperly in using Patriot Act to obtain thousands of business, financial and other records in United States; describes national security letters provided for under Patriot Act as administrative subpoenas (M)

headline.main: Bush Addresses Misuse of F.B.I. Subpoenas

docs.snippet: A Not-So-Close-Order Drill  Another practice or two is no doubt still in the offing for these members of the Knickerbocker Greys, a cadet corps for youngsters on the Upper East Side. The Greys have been a Manhattan institution for more than 125...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Not-So-Close-Order Drill Another practice or two is no doubt still in the offing for these members of the Knickerbocker Greys, a cadet corps for youngsters on the Upper East Side. The Greys have been a Manhattan institution for more than 125 years. PAGE 29 Deaths in Bronx, Tears in Mali As a family in the West African nation of Mali mourned loved ones who perished in a Bronx fire, word came that a 6-year-old relative had died, raising the death toll to 10. PAGE 29 Georgetown Takes Big East Georgetown won its first conference tournament since 1989; today, the men's N.C.A.A. tournament field will be selected. SPORTSSUNDAY Opinion: A Libby Pardon Frank Rich on the connection between the conviction of I. Lewis Libby Jr. and the mistreatment of troops at Walter Reed Army Medical Center. WEEK IN REVIEW, PAGE 14 Bush's Friend in Uruguay In Uruguay, President Bush visited a leader seen as willing to buck the anti-Americanism of regional strongmen like President Hugo Chávez of Venezuela. PAGE 4 History, Much Abridged In the Internet age, historical records that have not been converted to digital form could vanish from the nation's memory. SUNDAY BUSINESS

docs.snippet: President Bush also defended his decision to send more than 8,000 more troops to Iraq and Afghanistan, saying they would be dedicated to training and support missions.
docs.lead_paragraph: President Bush also defended his decision to send more than 8,000 more troops to Iraq and Afghanistan, saying they would be dedicated to training and support missions.
